thread.title: Wal-Mart’s whining because Amazon’s winning, analyst says
thread.title_full: Wal-Mart’s whining because Amazon’s winning, analyst says - MarketWatch

author: By     Tomi Kilgore
title: Wal-Mart’s whining because Amazon’s winning, analyst says
text:
FactSet No wonder Wal-Mart took a swing at Amazon Methinks Wal-Mart Stores Inc. doth protest too much, Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster said in so many words.
The world’s largest bricks-and-mortar retailer has taken aim at e-commerce giant Amazon.com Inc. recently, by rolling out an unlimited shipping service for $50 a year , which is about half what Amazon charges for its Amazon Prime service. Wal-Mart said it would also offer its own deals day , in response to Amazon’s Prime Day event on Wednesday.
Munster said he believes Wal-Mart’s reaction comes from a position of weakness, and is a sign of desperation. Especially considering Wal-Mart’s stock WMT, -0.12% has lost 14% so far this year, while Amazon shares AMZN, +1.27% have soared 55% to a fresh record on Friday.
“Wal-Mart’s attempt to create a competitive offering to Amazon shows the power Amazon is exerting as it gains loyalty and takes share from traditional retailers,” Munster wrote in a note to clients. “We think Wal-Mart’s response to Amazon indicates it is grasping for anything to attack Amazon.”
This is highlighted by the social media buzz surrounding Amazon’s Prime Day, while Wal-Mart’s deals day went mostly unnoticed.
Twitter data indicates Prime Day far outstrips Wal-Mart deals Tweet Content Tweets on July 15 Tospy Sentiment Score Prime Day tweets 98,600 66 Wal-Mart deals tweets 726 56 Sources: Piper Jaffray Web Analytics, Topsy, Spredfast data Although Munster acknowledged that many tweets about Prime Day were negative, as they poked fun at some of the products on sale , he reckons that is better than being ignored.
To make matters worse, Walmart.com Chief Executive Fernando Madeira took a swing at Amazon in a blog post earlier this week, but missed the target.
“We’ve heard some retailers are charging $100 to get access to a sale. But the idea of asking customers to pay extra in order to save money just doesn’t add up for us,” Madeira wrote .
Munster said that was a “strange statement” for two reasons:
• Prime Day included a free trial of the Amazon Prime service, so you didn’t need $100 to get access to the sale.
• Wal-Mart owns Sam’s Club, a membership-based warehouse retailer focused on providing lower prices.
“Aside from a seemingly counterintuitive message to consumers, we believe this highlights the level of concern Wal-Mart and other retailers have towards Amazon,” Munster said.
More from MarketWatch
